t: Mark 7
The Traditions of the Elders
The*p Pharisees and some of the scribes who had come from Jerusalem gathered around him.
They observed that some of his disciples were eating bread with unclean- that is, unwashed - hands.
(For the Pharisees and all the Jews do not eat unless they give their hands a ceremonial washing, keeping the tradition of the elders.

When they come from the marketplace, they do not eat unless they have washed. And there are many other customs they have received and keep, like the washing of cups, pitchers, kettles, and dining couches.)
So the Pharisees and the scribes asked him, “Why don’t your disciples live according to the tradition of the elders, instead of eating bread with ceremonially unclean hands?”

He*p answered them, “Isaiah*r prophesied*r correctly*r about*r you*r hypocrites,*r as*r it*r is*r written:*r This*irpn people*ir honors*ir me*ir with*ir their*ir lips,*ir but*irln their*ir heart*ir is*ir far*ir from*ir me.*ir
They*irln worship*ir me*ir in*ir vain,*ir teaching*irln as*ir doctrines*ir human*ir commands.*ir
Abandoning*rp the*r command*r of*r God,*r you*r hold*r on*r to*r human*r tradition.”*r
He also said to them, “You*r have*r a*r fine*r way*r of*r invalidating*r God’s*r command*r in*r order*r to*r set*r up*r your*r tradition!*r
For*r Moses*r said:*r Honor*ir your*ir father*ir and*ir your*ir mother;*ir and*r Whoever*ir speaks*ir evil*ir of*ir father*ir or*ir mother*ir must*ir be*ir put*ir to*ir death.*ir
But*r you*r say,*r ‘If*r anyone*r tells*r his*r father*r or*r mother:*r Whatever*r benefit*r you*r might*r have*r received*r from*r me*r is*r corban*br ’”*r (that is, an offering devoted to God),
“you*r no*r longer*r let*r him*r do*r anything*r for*r his*r father*r or*r mother.*r
You*r nullify*r the*r word*r of*r God*r by*r your*r tradition*r that*r you*r have*r handed*r down.*r And*r you*r do*r many*r other*r similar*r things.”*r
Summoning*p the crowd again, he told them, “Listen*r to*r me,*r all*r of*r you,*r and*r understand:*r
Nothing*r that*r goes*r into*r a*r person*r from*r outside*r can*r defile*r him*r but*r the*r things*r that*r come*r out*r of*r a*r person*r are*r what*r defile*r him.”*r
When*p he went into the house away from the crowd, his disciples asked him about the parable.
He said to them, “Are*r you*r also*r as*r lacking*r in*r understanding?*r Don’t*r you*r realize*r that*r nothing*r going*r into*r a*r person*r from*r the*r outside*r can*r defile*r him?*r
For*r it*r doesn’t*r go*r into*r his*r heart*r but*r into*r the*r stomach*r and*r is*r eliminated”*r (thus he declared all foods clean).
And he said, “What*r comes*r out*r of*r a*r person*r is*r what*r defiles*r him.*r
For*r from*r within,*r out*r of*r people’s*r hearts,*r come*r evil*r thoughts,*r sexual*r immoralities,*r thefts,*r murders,*r
adulteries,*r greed,*r evil*r actions,*r deceit,*r self-indulgence,*r envy,*r slander,*r pride,*r and*r foolishness.*r
All*r these*r evil*r things*r come*r from*r within*r and*r defile*r a*r person.”*r
A Gentile Mother’s Faith
He*p got up and departed from there to the region of Tyre. He entered a house and did not want anyone to know it, but he could not escape notice.
Instead, immediately after hearing about him, a woman whose little daughter had an unclean spirit came and fell at his feet.
The woman was a Gentile, a Syrophoenician by birth, and she was asking him to cast the demon out of her daughter.
He said to her, “Let*r the*r children*r be*r fed*r first,*r because*r it*r isn’t*r right*r to*r take*r the*r children’s*r bread*r and*r throw*r it*r to*r the*r dogs.”*r
But*p she replied to him, “Lord, even the dogs under the table eat the children’s crumbs.”
Then*p he told her, “Because*r of*r this*r reply,*r you*r may*r go.*r The*r demon*r has*r left*r your*r daughter.”*r
When she went back to her home, she found her child lying on the bed, and the demon was gone.
Jesus Does Everything Well
Again,*p leaving the region of Tyre, he went by way of Sidon to the Sea of Galilee, through the region of the Decapolis.
They brought to him a deaf man who had difficulty speaking and begged Jesus to lay his hand on him.
So he took him away from the crowd in private. After putting his fingers in the man’s ears and spitting, he touched his tongue.
Looking up to heaven, he sighed deeply and said to him, “Ephphatha!”*r (that is, “Be*r opened!”).*r
Immediately his ears were opened, his tongue was loosened, and he began to speak clearly.
He ordered them to tell no one, but the more he ordered them, the more they proclaimed it.
They*p were extremely astonished and said, “He has done everything well. He even makes the deaf hear and the mute speak.”
